revision.text:
{{tone|date=July 2017}}
The '''2016–17 Drought in Tamil Nadu''' is a disaster among the farmers of [[Tamil Nadu]]. This drought has happened due to the worst rainfall of last 140 years in Tamil Nadu. The rain bringing season of [[Northeast monsoon]] had left the farmers subdued with little rainfall.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.indiaspend.com/cover-story/ne-monsoon-worst-in-140-years-144-farmers-dead-tamil-nadu-declares-drought-89699 |title=NE Monsoon Worst In 140 Years, 144 Farmers Dead, Tamil Nadu Declares Drought |publisher=IndiaSpend |date=2017-01-10 |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref>
The drought had caused many farmer head of households to commit suicide.<ref>https://www.newsweek.com/2018/08/24/india-drought-suicides-climate-change-farmers-skulls-heat-disaster-1072699.html</ref>
==Northeast Monsoon== The year of 2016 has faced the worst rainfall in last 140 years in [[Tamil Nadu]]. In [[Tamil Nadu]] the average annual rainfall had gradually decreased 62% in 2016. The [[Northeast monsoon]] season had subdued over [[Tamil Nadu]] with the worse rainfall ever, just scattering rain in some areas.The highest deficit of normal rainfall in Indian states in 2016 is recorded in Tamil Nadu with 82% deficit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skymetweather.com/content/weather-news-and-analysis/northeast-monsoon-to-end-on-deficit-note-for-tamil-nadu/ |title=Northeast Monsoon to end on deficit note for Tamil Nadu |publisher=Skymet Weather |date=2016-12-21 |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref>
==Charred crops in Tamil Nadu== Agriculture in Tamil Nadu has faced a thunder like hit since the low rainfall had left the crops and agricultural lands with no water for irrigational purposes.Also the [[Kaveri River water dispute|Kaveri water issue]] became a huge headache for the farmers in Tamil Nadu, as no water is obtained from the tributaries of [[Kaveri river]] where it is the only source of irrigation for the Tamil Nadu farmers. The crops had severely charred in lakhs of hectares. It is said that the harvest in the year will be the worst ever in Tamil Nadu.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/india/tamil-nadu-declares-drought-as-144-farmers-die-amid-worst-north-east-monsoon-in-140-years-3197616.html |title=Tamil Nadu declares drought as 144 farmers die amid worst North East monsoon in 140 years |website=Firstpost.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref>
==Farmers death due to depression== Since the agricultural growth of crops had decreased and charred due to less water for irrigation, the farmers in Tamil Nadu requested the state to be announced as affected by drought. Many fasting strike and mass movements were held due to the delay of announcing Tamil Nadu as affected by drought.Farmers fell in deep depression because of indebtedness and charred crops in their fields. Tamil Nadu farmers fell ill and dead each day due to heart attack.
==Tamil Nadu announced drought-hit== On 10 January 2017, Chief Minister [[O. Panneerselvam]] announced that Tamil Nadu will be announced as drought-hit state. Since entire Tamil Nadu was devastated by the [[drought]] because of low rainfall, huge expenses will be incurred in protecting the people and central financial assistance will be sought because of this, he said. He further said that Rs.5465 per acre will be provided for farmers who suffered 33% loss sowing paddy and other irrigational crops and Rs.7287 per acre for long term crops.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/tn-to-be-declared-drought-hit-cm-announces-sops-for-farmers/1/853918.html |title=TN to be declared drought-hit; CM announces sops for farmers : PTI feed, News - India Today |website=Indiatoday.intoday.in |date=2017-01-10 |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref>
==Farmers Protest in Delhi== {{Main|2017 Tamil Nadu Farmers Protest}}
As announced by the TN Government the relief funds are not distributed evenly and not abandoning the loans of the farmers they got from the cooperative banks, they got frustrated.Since the Central and State government betrayed the Tamil Nadu farmers, they started to protest against the [[Central Government of India|central Government]] in [[Jantar Mantar, New Delhi]]. This protest
==References== {{Reflist}} *[https://thewire.in/117210/why-farmers-are-protesting-with-human-skulls-at-jantar-mantar/ Watch: Why Farmers Are Protesting With Human Skulls at Jantar Mantar]
{{DEFAULTSORT:2016-17 Drought in Tamil Nadu}} [[Category:Tamil Nadu]] [[Category:Droughts in Asia]] [[Category:Natural disaster deaths in India]] [[Category:Indian farmers]] [[Category:Farmers' suicides in India]] [[Category:2017 Tamil Nadu Farmers Protest]]

revision.text:
The '''Antwerpsche Diamantkring''' was established in 1928 in [[Antwerp]], Belgium, to become the first diamond bourse worldwide that is dedicated exclusively to rough diamonds trade.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.awdc.be/en/20th-century |title=The history of the Antwerp Diamond Center |publisher=Antwerp World Diamond Centre}}</ref>
It is a member of the [[World Federation of Diamond Bourses]].
85% of the world’s diamond supply is traded in Antwerp, and in particular in the Antwerpsche Diamantkring.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/inside-antwerps-secret-glittering-ultra-secure-diamond-hq-where-85-of-the-worlds-supply-changes-hands |title=Inside Antwerp’s secret, glittering, ultra-secure diamond HQ where 85% of the world’s supply changes hands |newspaper=National Post |date=December 9, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/belgium/10502563/Antwerps-secret-heart-of-the-31bn-global-diamond-trade.html |title=Antwerp's secret heart of the £31bn global diamond trade |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=December 7, 2013}}</ref>
==Presidents of the Board of Directors== * 1929-1957 Gustave Garitte * 1957-1961 Frans Beukelaar * 1961-1972 [[Israel Beck]] * 1973-1979 Michel Fraenkel * 1979-1987 Sammy Hutterer * 1987-1999 Isi Beck * 1999-2003 Gerson Goldschmidt * 2003-2012 David Wahl * 2012- Alfred (Freddy) Inzlicht
==Rough Diamond Day== The Rough Diamond Day is a biannual international event dedicated to rough diamonds trade, organized by the Antwerpsche Diamantkring.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.diamonds.net/News/NewsItem.aspx?ArticleID=48488&ArticleTitle=Antwerpsche+Diamantkring+Hosts+Rough+Diamond+Day |title=Antwerpsche Diamantkring Hosts Rough Diamond Day |website=Rapapport Diamonds.net}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.awdc.be/en/antwerpsche-diamantkring-orga |title=Antwerpsche Diamantkring organizes second Rough Diamond Day |website=Antwerp World Diamond Center}}</ref>
==External links== * [http://www.diamantkring.org// Antwerpsche Diamantkring website]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Antwerpsche Diamantkring}} [[Category:Business organisations based in Belgium]] [[Category:Companies based in Antwerp]] [[Category:Diamond exchanges]] [[Category:Commodity exchanges]] [[Category:Companies established in 1928]] [[Category:1928 establishments in Belgium]]
{{Belgium-stub}}

{{Infobox Radio station |name = Beijing Renmin Guangbo Diantai
(English: Beijing People's Broadcasting Station)
(北京人民广播电台) |image = Bjradiochina.png |area = [[Beijing]], {{CHN}} |airdate = 1949 |frequency = FM 94.5 MHz FM 97.4 MHz, FM 100.6 MHz, FM 103.9 MHz, FM 107.3 MHz, AM 603 kHz, AM 774 kHz, AM 828 kHz, AM 927 kHz, Internet |format = Contemporary |owner = |website = [http://www.rbc.cn/ http://www.rbc.cn/] }} {{Infobox Chinese |showflag=stp |t=北京人民廣播電臺 |s=北京人民广播电台 |p=Běijīng Rénmín Guǎngbō Diàntái |w= |j=Bak1ging1 Jan4man4 Gwong2bo3 Din6toi4 |y= |order=st }} '''Beijing Renmin Guangbo Diantai''' ({{zh|s=北京人民广播电台|p=Běijīng Rénmín Guǎngbō Diàntái}}), is a family of municipal radio stations that also include news, music, and sports in Beijing. The Mandarin name translates literally as '''Beijing People's Broadcasting Station''', however in recent years it has preferred the style '''Radio Beijing Corporation'''.http://topic.rbc.cn/08xxy_2/dtlj/200808/t20080807_714281.htm {{dead link|date=May 2017}} Beijing Radio broadcasts in Beijing on AM, FM, cable FM, digital radio, digital TV and online. ==List of Beijing Radio Stations== {{Expand list|date=August 2008}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ '''Beijing Radio Stations''' !Frequency/Internet !Description |- | [[Beijing Xinwen Guangbo|Beijing News Radio]] - Internet Streaming/FM 103.9 MHz | Traffic |- | Jiaoxue (教学) - Internet Streaming/99.4 FM | Class Radio for Languages and Beijing Radio & TV University |- | Wenyi (文艺) - Internet Streaming/87.6 FM | Chinese Literature Broadcast |- | [[Beijing Tiyu Guangbo|Beijing Sport Radio]] (体育) - Internet Streaming/AM 927 kHz/FM 102.5 MHz | Sports Broadcast |- | [[Beijing Yinyue Tai|Beijing Music Radio]] (音乐) - Internet Streaming/FM 97.4 MHz | Beijing Music Radio (Mandopop) |- | Shenghuo - Internet Streaming | Beijing City Life Broadcast |- | Qingyinyue - revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} The second '''Congress of Visegrád''' was a 1339 [[summit (meeting)|summit]] in [[Visegrád]] where it was decided that after the death of [[Casimir III of Poland]], the son of [[Charles I of Hungary]], [[Louis I of Hungary]], would become King of Poland provided that Kazimierz does not have a son. This actually also happened.
When Casimir died in 1370 from an injury received while hunting, his nephew, King [[Louis I of Hungary]], succeeded him as king of Poland in [[personal union]] with [[Hungary]].
==See also== * [[Congress of Visegrád (1335)]] * [[Visegrád group]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Congress Of Visegrad (1339)}} [[Category:14th century in Hungary|Congress of Visegrad]] [[Category:Diplomatic conferences in Hungary|Visegrad]] [[Category:14th-century diplomatic conferences|Visegrad]] [[Category:1339 in Bohemia]] [[Category:14th century in Poland]]
{{Europe-hist-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Foyer S.A. | logo = Foyer logo.gif | logo_size = 170px | image = File:Foyer S.A. Group Luxembourg - Front - July 2012.jpg | type = [[S.A. (corporation)|Société Anonyme]] | traded_as = {{LuxSE|isin=LU0112960504|FOY}} | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 28 October 1922 | founder = Léon Laval, Max Lambert, Joseph Bach and Max Menager | defunct = | location_city = [[Luxembourg (city)|Luxembourg]] | location_country = [[Luxembourg]] | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Henri Marx (Chairman)
François Tesch (Chief Executive Officer) | industry = Insurance | products = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.foyer.lu/}} | footnotes = }} '''Foyer S.A.''' is an [[insurance]] company, based in [[Leudelange]], in south-western [[Luxembourg]]. The company offers services to both individuals and businesses, covering a range of products, including: [[life insurance]], [[car insurance]], [[home insurance]], [[health insurance]], [[liability insurance]], [[travel insurance]], and [[savings]] products for individuals;{{cite web |url=http://www.foyer.lu/index.php?lefoyer_private_persons_index |title=Personal products |accessdate=2007-08-24 |date= |publisher=Foyer |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928141613/http://www.foyer.lu/index.php?lefoyer_private_persons_index |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }} and [[health insurance]], [[group insurance]], and [[corporate-owned life insurance]] for businesses.{{cite web |url=http://www.foyer.lu/index.php?lefoyer_corporations_index |title=Business products |accessdate=2007-08-24 |date= |publisher=Foyer |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928141637/http://www.foyer.lu/index.php?lefoyer_corporations_index |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }} ==History== The company was founded in 1922 by Léon Laval, Max Lambert, Joseph Bach and Max Menager{{cite web |url=http://groupe.foyer.lu/en/foyer/our-history |title=Our history |publisher=Foyer |accessdate=22 July 2017}} as '''Le Foyer, Compagnie Luxembourgeoise d'Assurances S.A.''',{{cite web |url=http://groupe.foyer.lu/en/foyer/our-history/key-dates |title=Key dates |publisher=Foyer |accessdate=22 July 2017}} a name that was changed to 'Foyer' in 2005. Foyer is listed on the [[Luxembourg Stock Exchange]], where it is a smallest of the ten component companies of the main [[LuxX Index]] [[stock market index]], and [[Euronext Brussels]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.foyer.lu Foyer official website] {{Portal|Companies}} {{LuxX companies}} [[Category:Insurance companies of Luxembourg]] [[Category:Leudelange]] [[Category:Financial services companies established in 1922]] [[Category:Brands of Luxembourg]] [[Category:1922 establishments in Luxembourg]] {{Luxembourg-stub}} {{Europe-company-stub}} {{Insurance-company-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} '''Gleti''' is a [[moon goddess]] from the [[Africa]]n kingdom of [[Dahomey]], situated in what is now [[Benin]].
In [[Dahomey mythology]], she is the mother of all the stars. An [[eclipse]] is caused by the shadow of the moon’s husband crossing her face.
[[Category:Lunar goddesses]] [[Category:Dahomey goddesses]] [[Category:African mythology]]
{{Africa-myth-stub}}

{{Multiple issues| {{More footnotes|date=February 2008}} {{refimprove|date=December 2011}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} '''Globalization of wine''' is the expansion of [[wine]] [[varietal]]s and [[brand]]s across nations and to other continents, especially in modern times as a result of the advent of air travel and access to wine information via the [[internet]]. ==History== {{main article|History of wine}} {{unreferenced section|date=June 2012}} Wine has been traded internationally since ancient times. In the wake of the [[amphora]]s came professional winemakers, winemaking techniques, and cuttings of grapevines. Many grapes that are considered 'traditional' in Western Europe were in fact brought by ancient trade routes from the Eastern Mediterranean and the Black Sea region. The [[Phoenicians (wine)|Phoenicians]], the [[Greeks (wine)|Greeks]], the [[Romans (wine)|Romans]], the [[Armenian wine|Armenians]] all brought grapes to new homes. There was a second wave of migration to the New World, under the European empires of the 16th–19th centuries – by the early 18th century South Africa was exporting [[Constantia (wine)|Constantia]] to Europe, made with muscat grapes that originated in [[Egypt]]. Subsequent immigrants have brought their native wines and grapes wherever they have gone – the Italian influence on Argentine and Californian winemaking is particularly noteworthy. Wines from [[Portugal]] and [[Madeira]] were fortified to survive journeys across the world, and left their mark on wines in the colonies that aped their style and were named after them. The [[phylloxera]] epidemic of the late 19th century also had a big influence, destroying traditional field blends of indigenous grapes in vineyards, which were often replaced by monocultures of fashionable grapes such as the [[Bordeaux]] varieties – grafted, of course, onto rootstocks from North America. Vignerons faced a stark choice, either adopt the new techniques, or choose another profession. Phylloxera was the stimulus for the development of a new infrastructure of government breeding programmes and exchange of plant material and techniques. After the [[Second World War]], a number of countries developed bland wines for the export market, with an emphasis on uniformity and branding, such as [[Mateus (wine brand)|Mateus Rose]] and [[Blue Nun]]. These were welcomed by a mass market – and the multiple retailers who served them – and those same factors have helped similar brands to gain more power, although changes in fashion mean that the names have changed. The modern equivalents come from industrial [[irrigated vineyards]] in the New World, in regions such as Murray Darling in southern Australia and Worcester in South Africa. Such moves reflect changes in the general scale of food production in industrialised countries. Another aspect of this is the rise of varietal labelling, which has made the big companies less tolerant of blends of obscure grapes, instead preferring to market 'big name' varietals such as [[Cabernet Sauvignon]], [[Merlot]], [[Pinot noir]], [[Syrah]] (Shiraz), [[Chardonnay]], [[Sauvignon blanc]] and [[Riesling]]. Another growing trend has been the practice of the blending of bulk wine from other countries with local wine. In some cases, a wine marketed as a local product may be sourced entirely from elsewhere. Regulations on this practice vary widely, depending on the jurisdiction. The [[Judgment of Paris (wine)|Judgment of Paris]] in 1976 and subsequent [[wine competitions]] helped winemakers throughout the New World realize that they could make wines equal to the very best produced anywhere in the world as well educating some markets about the potential of wine outside Europe. This process was much easier in some countries like England, with little indigenous production and a centuries-old tradition of importing wine from around the world, than it was in other countries. Further competitions brought to international attention other great wines from around the world, some of which like [[Penfolds Grange]] had already been made for decades. A major influence has been the wine critic [[Robert M. Parker, Jr.]] among consumers in the United States. His approval can make a massive difference to sales of a wine in the United States, and some winemakers in some parts of the world have been accused of chasing this market by changing their wines to suit his personal taste. This effect is the main subject of the documentary film ''[[Mondovino]]''. His points system is influential, particularly among retailers as a substitute for staff training. ==Return to ''terroir''== On the other hand, as New World winemaking has matured, winemakers have taken more notice of ''[[terroir]]'', and matching grapes and winemaking styles to particular locations. Thus New World styles are starting to develop, such as [[Clare Valley]] Riesling, [[Marlborough Region|Marlborough]] Sauvignon Blanc, and 'indigenous' varieties such as [[Pinotage]] are being proudly marketed as single-varietal wines rather than blended. In Europe, there is renewed interest in heritage wines, particularly by the new democracies in Eastern Europe where wine can be a statement of national identity. A particularly good example is seen in [[Eger]] in Hungary, where the local [[Egri Bikavér|Bull's Blood]] wine has seen a steady infusion of foreign grapes such as [[Blaufränkisch]] in the 18th century, the Bordeaux varieties after ''[[phylloxera]]'' struck, and [[Zweigelt]] under communism. This is now being reversed with substantial new planting of the traditional [[Kadarka]] variety. ==Production== {{Main article|Winemaking}} {{See also|List of wine-producing countries|List of wine-producing regions}} {| class="wikitable" |+'''Wine production by country 2011'''{{cite web |url=http://faostat.fao.org/site/636/DesktopDefault.aspx?PageID=636#ancor |title= Wine production (tons) |publisher= [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] |page=28 |accessdate=2012-04-23}} ! Rank !! Country
(with link to wine article) !! Production
([[tonne]]s) |- | 1 || {{flagicon|France}} [[French wine|France]] || 6,590,750 |- | 2 || {{flagicon|Italy}} [[Italian wine|Italy]] || 4,673,400 |- | 3 || {{flagicon|Spain}} [[Spanish wine|Spain]] || 3,339,700 |- | 4 || {{flagicon|United States}} [[American wine|United States]] || 2,211,300 |- | 5 || {{flagicon|China}} [[Chinese grape wine|China]] || 1,657,500 |- | 6 || {{flagicon|Argentina}} 79,000 |- | 26 || {{flagicon|Peru}} [[Peruvian wine|Peru]] || 72,700 |- | 27 || {{flagicon|Macedonia}} [[Macedonian wine|Macedonia]] || 66,530 |- | 28 || {{flagicon|Uruguay}} [[Uruguayan wine|Uruguay]] || 65,000 |- | 29 || {{flagicon|Croatia}} [[Croatian wine|Croatia]] || 48,875 |- | 30 || {{flagicon|Algeria}} [[Algerian wine|Algeria]] || 47,500 |- | 31 || {{flagicon|Canada}} [[Canadian wine|Canada]] || 46,851 |- | 32 || {{flagicon|Czech Republic}} [[Czech wine|Czech Republic]] || 45,000 |- | 33 || {{flagicon|Morocco}} [[Moroccan wine|Morocco]] || 33,300 |- | 34 || {{flagicon|Slovakia}} [[Slovakian wine|Slovakia]] || 31,388 |- | 35 || {{flagicon|Turkey}} [[Turkish wine|Turkey]] || 27,950 |- | 36 || {{flagicon|Mexico}} [[Mexican wine|Mexico]] || 27,609 |- | 37 || {{flagicon|Belarus}} [[Belarusian wine|Belarus]] || 27,320 |- | 38 || {{flagicon|Slovenia}} [[Slovenian wine|Slovenia]] || 24,000 |- | 39 || {{flagicon|Tunisia}} [[Tunisian wine|Tunisia]] || 23,200 |- | 40 || {{flagicon|Uzbekistan}} [[Uzbekistani wine|Uzbekistan]] || 21,000 |- |} Wine grapes grow almost exclusively between thirty and fifty degrees north or south of the [[equator]]. The world's southernmost vineyards are in the [[Central Otago wine|Central Otago]] region of [[New Zealand wine|New Zealand]]'s [[South Island]] near the [[45th parallel south]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.wineoftheweek.com/regions/otago.html |title=New Zealand Wine Regions - Central Otago |accessdate=26 June 2008 |last=Courtney |first=Sue |date=16 April 2005}} and the northernmost are in [[Flen]], [[Sweden]], just north of the [[59th parallel north]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.beer100.com/history/winehistory.htm |title=Wine History |accessdate=26 June 2008}} ==See also== *[[List of wine-producing regions]] *[[New World wine]] *[[Old World wine]] *[[International variety]] ==Sources== * The Globalization of Wine, chapter 22 in: Taber, George M. ''Judgment of Paris: California vs. Paris and the Historic 1976 Paris Tasting that Revolutionized Wine''. NY: Scribner, 2005. * Rachman, Gideon. The Globe in a Glass. ''The Economist'', 16-12-99 [http://www.economist.com/surveys/displayStory.cfm?story_id=268095].{{subscription}} ==Notes== {{Wines}} {{portal bar|Drink}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Globalization Of Wine}} [[Category:Wine]] [[Category:Economic globalization]]

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Finland}} "Huilumies" | image = [[Image:Eurovision Song Contest 1980 postcards - Vesa-Matti Loiri 11.png|250px]] | caption = | year = 1980 | country = Finland | artist = [[Vesa-Matti Loiri]] | as = | with = | language = Finnish | languages = | composer = [[Aarno Raninen]] | lyricist = [[Vexi Salmi|Veikko 'Vexi' Salmi]] | conductor = [[Ossi Runne]] | place = 19th | points = 6 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1980fi from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Katson sineen taivaan | prev_link = Katson sineen taivaan | next = Reggae OK | next_link = Reggae OK }} '''"Huilumies"''' ([[English Language|English]] translation: "A Flute Man") was the [[Finland|Finnish]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1980]], performed in [[Finnish Language|Finnish]] by [[Vesa-Matti Loiri]]. The song was composed by [[Aarno Raninen]], who also had composed 1977 entry "[[Lapponia (song)|Lapponia]]". In turn, lyricist [[Vexi Salmi|Veikko 'Vexi' Salmi]] had also written the lyrics to 1979 entry "[[Katson sineen taivaan]]".
The song was performed tenth on the night (following [[Switzerland]]'s [[Paola (singer)|Paola]] with "[[Cinéma (song)|Cinéma]]" and preceding [[Norway]]'s [[Sverre Kjelsberg]] & [[Mattis Hætta]] with "[[Sámiid Ædnan]]"). At the close of voting, it had received 6 points, placing 19th (last) in a field of 19.
The song is sung from the perspective of the tititular "flute man", who sings that while he may not be able to express his feelings in words, he is able to do so with his flute.
It was succeeded as [[Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest|Finnish representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1981|1981 Contest]] by [[Riki Sorsa]] with "[[Reggae OK]]".
==References== * [http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=296 Official Eurovision Song Contest site, history by year]
{{Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1980}}
[[Category:Eurovision songs of Finland]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1980]] [[Category:1980 songs]] [[Category:Songs with lyrics by Vexi Salmi]]
{{Finland-stub}}

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category True Orthodox Church to [[:Category:Сatacomb Church]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
'''Josephites''' ({{lang-ru|иосифляне}} ''Iosiflyane'') so-called after the name of the Metropolitan [[Joseph (Petrovykh)]] of [[Petrograd]] – leader of resistance in [[Russian Orthodox Church]].
The resistance began after Metropolitan [[Patriarch Sergius I of Moscow|Sergius (Stragorodsky)]] issued formal declaration to all members of the Church, called for loyalty toward the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] government: “… ''We need to prove it by not words but deeds that not only those indifferent to the Orthodoxy, not only its betrayers can be loyal citizens of the Soviet Union but also its most fervent adherents for whom it is as dear as the truth and life with all its dogmas and traditions, all its canonical and service ways. We want to be Orthodox and simultaneously view the Soviet Union as our civil fatherland, whose joys and achievements are our joys and achievements and failures are our failures''”
==References== <references/>
==External links== * Mikhail Shkarovsky. The Russian Orthodox Church versus the State: The Josephite Movement, 1927–1940 // Slavic Review (Boston). 1995. Vol. 54. № 2. Summer. Р. 365–384 * Mikhail Shkarovsky. Josif (Petrovych), in irriducibile della fede // La nuova Europa (Bergamo, Italia). 2002. N 1. P. 83–94. * Михаил Шкаровский Судьбы иосифлянских пастырей: Иосифлянское движение Русской Православной Церкви в судьбах его участников. СПб., 2006.
{{Russia-stub}} {{Christian-denomination-stub}} [[Category:Сatacomb Church]] [[Category:Eastern Orthodox organizations established in the 20th century]] [[Category:20th-century Eastern Orthodoxy]]

{{Infobox former country | conventional_long_name = Kel Ahaggar
Ihaggarren
ⴾⵍ ⵂⴴⵔ | common_name = ⴾⵍ ⵂⴴⵔ | status = Tuareg confederation | image_flag = Flag of Kel Ahaggar.svg | image_flag2 = | image_coat = | coat_alt = | symbol_type = | image_map = Kel Ahaggar Map.png | image_map_caption = Kel Ahaggar Tuareg confederation Map | continent = Africa | region = North Africa | life_span = | event_start = Kel Ahaggar established | year_start = 1750 | event1 = Under French suzerainty | date_event1 = 1903 | event2 = not recognized by independent [[Algeria]] | date_event2 = 1962 | event_end = terminated by [[Algerian Government]] | year_end = 1977 | s1 = Algeria | capital = [[Hoggar Mountains]], [[Algeria]] | common_languages = [[Berber languages|Berber]] | religion = [[Islam]] | government_type = [[Confederation|Tribal Confederacy]] | title_leader = [[Amenokal]] | leader1 = [[Tin Hinan]] | year_leader1 = | currency = | today = {{flag|Algeria}} }} '''Kel Ahaggar''' ([[Berber languages|Berber]]: ⴾⵍ ⵂⴴⵔ) (trans: "People of Ahaggar") is a [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] confederation inhabiting the [[Hoggar Mountains]] (Ahaggar mountains) in [[Algeria]]. The confederation is believed to have been founded by the Tuareg matriarch [[Tin Hinan]], whose monumental [[Tin Hinan Tomb|tomb]] is located at [[Abalessa]]. The official establishment is dated to around 1750. It has been largely defunct since 1977, when it was terminated by the [[Algeria|Algerian government]]. The language of the confederation is ''Tahaggart'', a dialect of [[Tamahaq language|Tamahaq]]. == Tribes == The Kel Ahaggar confederation is made up of a number of tribes, including: *[[Aït Loaien]] *[[Dag Rali]] (also spelled Dag Ghâli) *[[Iregenaten]] *[[Kel Rela]], the ruling tribe. *[[Kel Silet]] *[[Taituq]] *[[Tégéhé Millet]] == See also == *[[Rulers of Kel Ahaggar]] *[[Tuareg people]] **[[Kel Adagh]] **[[Kel Ajjer]] **[[Kel Ayr]] **[[Kel Gres]] **[[Iwellemmedan people]]: Kel Ataram (west) and Kel Dinnik (east) ==In popular culture== *{{cite book |first=David |last=Ball |authorlink=David W. Ball |title=Empires of Sand |publisher=Bantam |year=1999 |ISBN=0-553-11014-4}} A novel about the 1881 attempt by the French government to drive a railroad through the heart of the Sahara, including the Ahaggar region. The expedition, led by Lt. Colonel [[Paul Flatters]], was attacked by the Tuareg of the Kel Ahaggar. == External links == * https://web.archive.org/web/20070930191707/http://sea.unep-wcmc.org/sites/pa/1460v.htm * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050907005529/http://www.petrabode.privat.t-online.de/his1.htm Kel Ahaggar] (in German) * https://web.archive.org/web/20050922005745/http://www.petrabode.privat.t-online.de/detail.htm (in German) [[Category:African nomads]] [[Category:Berber history]] [[Category:Maghreb]] [[Category:Sahara]] [[Category:Algerian society]] [[Category:Tuareg confederations]] {{berber-stub}} {{Africa-hist-stub}}

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Koryak]] (link changed to [[Koryaks]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} The [[Chukchi people|Chukchi]] creator-deity, roughly analogous to [[Bai-Ulgan]] of the [[Turkish folklore|Turkic]] pantheon. The [[Koryaks|Koryak]] refer to him as ''Quikinna'qu'' ("Big Raven") and in [[Kamchadal]] mythology he is called ''[[Kutkh|Kutkhu]]''.
== See also ==
* [[Kutkh]]
[[Category:Siberian deities]] [[Category:Chukchi people]] [[Category:Circumpolar mythology]]
{{Siberia-myth-stub}}

{{Infobox sports league | title = Liga I | current_season = | caption = | folded = 2018 | fame = | motto = | sport = [[Basketball]] | founded = | teams = 25 | champion = [[BC Timba Timișoara|Timba Timișoara]]
(2016–17) | most_champs = | level = 2 | promotion = [[Liga Națională (men's basketball)|Liga Națională]] | relegation = Liga II | singles = | continent = {{flagicon|EU}} [[FIBA Europe]] | country = {{ROU}} | related_comps = [[Romanian Basketball Cup]] | ceo = | TV = | website = {{URL|http://www.frbaschet.ro/}} {{ro icon}} }} The '''Liga I''' was the second level of professional [[basketball]] in [[Romania]]. There were 25 teams, divided in 4 groups in Liga I.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurobasket.com/Romania/basketball.asp|title=Romanian Basketball, News, Teams, Scores, Stats, Standings, Awards - eurobasket|publisher=}} The competition was dissolved at the start of the 2018–19 season, when the Romanian Basketball System was reformed and [[Liga Națională (men's basketball)|Liga Națională]] remained the only senior level competition.[http://www.frbaschet.ro/stiri/2018-05-25/decizii-ale-consiliului-director-din-23-05-2018 Decizii ale Consiliului Director din 23.05.2018]. frbaschet.ro {{ro}}[http://totalbaschet.ro/articol/Cum-va-ar%C4%83ta-Liga-Na%C8%9Bional%C4%83-de-Baschet-Masculin-sezonul-viitor~62188 Cum va arăta Liga Națională de Baschet Masculin sezonul viitor]. totalbaschet.ro {{ro}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.24secunde.ro/ 24secunde.ro (Romanian)] *[http://www.totalbaschet.ro/ TotalBaschet.ro (Romanian)] *[http://www.frbaschet.ro/ Official site of the Romanian basketball federation] *[http://www.baschetromania.ro/ Baschetromania.ro] (Romanian) *[http://www.eurobasket.com/Romania/basketball.asp Romanian league on Eurobasket] {{DEFAULTSORT:Liga I (men's basketball)}} [[Category:Basketball competitions in Romania]] [[Category:Basketball leagues in Europe]] {{Romania-stub}}

revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox radio station | image = [[File:RaypowerAbuja Logo.png|200px|RaypowerAbuja Logo]] | name = RaypowerAbuja | slogan = The Ultimate In style | airdate = 1 January 2005 | frequency = [[FM broadcasting|FM]]: 100.5[[Hertz|MHz]] | area = Nigeria | city = [[Abuja]], [[Federal Capital Territory, Nigeria|FCT]] | format = [[Afrobeats]]
and [[urban contemporary]] | owner = [[DAAR Communications Plc]] | sister_stations = [[Raypower 100.5 FM Lagos]] Raypower Kaduna, Raypower Benin, Raypower Port Harcourt, Raypower Jos, Raypower Kano, Raypower Yenagoa, Raypower Enugu, Raypower Ilorin, Raypower Katsina, Raypower Makurdi, Raypower Yola, Raypower Bauchi, Raypower Gombe, Raypower Maiduguri, Raypower Owerri, Raypower Osogbo, Raypower Agenebode and Raypower Calabar. }} '''Raypower Abuja''' is an independent private Nigerian [[radio station]] that broadcasts on the 100.5 FM frequency from [[Abuja]], [[Federal Capital Territory, Nigeria|FCT]], Nigeria. It started broadcasting on January 1, 2005. == History == In the wake of deregulation of broadcasting on 24th August 1992, DAAR Communications Plc applied for and was granted approval to operate an independent radio station. The station which started test transmission on the 15th of December, 1993 made history on the 1st of September, 1994 when it commenced commercial broadcasting with the launch of [[Raypower 100.5 FM|Raypower 100.5 fm]] in [[Lagos]] as the first 24-hour broadcast service station in Nigeria as well as the first private independent broadcasting station in the country. ==External links == *[http://www.raypowerradio.com Raypower website] {{coord missing|Nigeria}} [[Category:Radio stations in Nigeria]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 2005]] [[Category:Media in Abuja]] [[Category:2005 establishments in Nigeria]] {{Nigeria-radio-station-stub}}

{{infobox ethnic group |group = Turkish Serbs |native_name = Срби у Турској
Srbi u Turskoj |total = 15,000 |total_year=2010 |total_ref=http://kirs.gov.rs/docs/migracije/Migration_Profile_of_the_Republic_of_Serbia_for_2010.pdf |popplace = [[Istanbul]], [[Gallipoli]] |languages = [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Serbian language|Serbian]] |religions = [[Sunni Islam]] and [[Serbian Orthodox]] |related = }} {{Serbs}} The '''Serbs in Turkey''' are [[Turkish people|Turkish]] citizens of [[Serbs|Serbian]] descent or [[Serbia]]-born people who reside in [[Turkey]]. ==History== During the age of the [[Ottoman Empire]] most of Serbia and the Balkans were under Turkish control, and many Serbs moved to [[Istanbul]] and [[Anatolia]] for reasons ranging from economic to forceful relocation. Many [[Janissaries]] were of Serbian descent and were taken as children from their homes and educated in Turkey. Some Serbs achieved political prominence and several [[List of Ottoman Grand Viziers|Grand Viziers]] were born Serbs. ==Demographics== According to the 1965 Census 6,599 Turkish citizen spoke [[Serbian language|Serbian]] as a first language and another 58,802 spoke [[Serbian language|Serbian]] as a second language.[[Demographics of Turkey#1965 census]] ==Notable people== *[[Zagan Pasha]], Ottoman Grand Vizier from 1453 to 1456 *[[Mahmud Pasha Angelović]], [[List of Ottoman Grand Viziers|Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire]] from 1456 to 1466, and 1472 to 1474 *[[Sokollu Mehmed Pasha]], [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] Grand Vizier from 1565 to 1579 *[[Sokolluzade Lala Mehmed Pasha]], Ottoman Grand Vizier from 1604 to 1606 *[[Damat Melek Mehmed Pasha]], Ottoman Grand Vizier from 1792 to 1794 *[[Yavuz Ali Pasha]], [[List of Ottoman governors of Egypt|Ottoman Governor of Egypt]] from 1601 to 1603 *[[Meylişah Hatun]], Consort to [[Sultan]] [[Osman II]] *[[Ivana Sert]], famous Serbian-Turkish television personality, socialite, presenter, model, fashion designer, entrepreneur, businesswoman, beauty pageant titleholder, author and occasional actress ==See also== {{Portal|Turkey|Serbia}} * [[Gallipoli Serbs]] * [[Belgrad Forest]] *[[Asia Minor Slavs]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Demographics of Turkey}} {{Serbian diaspora}} [[Category:European diaspora in Turkey]] [[Category:Turkish people of Serbian descent| ]] [[Category:Serbian diaspora]] [[Category:Serb diaspora]] {{Serbia-stub}} {{Turkey-stub}}

revision.comment: Sportscorrection moved page [[Tatlısu Halk Odası S.K.]] to [[Tatlısu Halk Odası Beylerbeyi S.K.]]: The club's actual name is Tatlısu Halk Odası Beylerbeyi Spor Kulübü

page.title: Theory of the Undetermined Status of Taiwan

revision.text:
The '''Theory of the Undetermined Status of Taiwan''' ({{zh|'''台灣地位未定論'''}}), also called the '''Theory of the Undetermined Sovereignty of Taiwan''' ({{zh|'''台灣主權未定論'''}}), is one of the theories which describe the [[island of Taiwan]]'s present legal status.
The theory originated from United States President [[Harry S. Truman]]'s statement on 27 June 1950, regarding the [[Korean War]], which had broken out two days earlier. In his statement, Truman said that it would be a direct threat to the [[United States]]' security in the western [[Pacific]] area if the communist forces occupied Taiwan, so he ordered the [[7th Fleet]] to enter the [[Taiwan Strait]] to prevent any attack on the island. Truman stated: "The determination of the future status of [[Formosa]] must await the restoration of security in the Pacific, a peace settlement with [[Japan]], or consideration by the [[United Nations]]."<ref name="Statement by the President on the Situation in Korea">{{cite web | author = [[Harry S. Truman]] | title = Statement by the President on the Situation in Korea | url = http://www.trumanlibrary.org/publicpapers/viewpapers.php?pid=800 | website = [[Harry S. Truman Library and Museum]] | date = 27 June 1950 | accessdate = 2 September 2015}}</ref> Because of the statement, the Theory of the Undetermined Status of Taiwan came into existence.
Although Japan concluded the [[Treaty of San Francisco]] with the [[Allies of World War II|Allied Powers]] after [[World War II]] in 1951, in the treaty it merely "renounced" all right, title and claim<ref>{{cite wikisource | date= 8 September 1951 | title = Treaty of San Francisco | quote = Chapter II. Territory – Article 2 – (b) Japan renounces all right, title and claim to Formosa and the Pescadores.}}</ref> to Taiwan and the [[Pescadores]] without explicitly stating the sovereignty status of the two territories. Therefore, the Theory of the Undetermined Status of Taiwan is still supported by some politicians and jurists to this day.<ref>{{Cite web | author = Shirley A. Kan; Wayne M. Morrison | title = U.S.-Taiwan Relationship: Overview of Policy Issues | url = http://fas.org/sgp/crs/row/R41952.pdf | format = PDF | publisher = [[Congressional Research Service]] | location = [[Washington, D.C.]] | date = 11 December 2014 | page = 4 | quote = The United States has its own "one China" policy (vs. the PRC's "one China" principle) and position on Taiwan's status. Not recognizing the PRC's claim over Taiwan nor Taiwan as a sovereign state, U.S. policy has considered Taiwan's status as unsettled.}}</ref><ref name="日本外交界常識">{{cite news | author=曾韋禎 | script-title = 台灣主權未定論 許世楷：日本外交界常識 | trans-title = [[Koh Se-kai]]: Theory of the Undetermined Sovereignty of Taiwan Is a General Knowledge in the Japanese Diplomatic Community | url = http://news.ltn.com.tw/news/focus/paper/300420 | newspaper = [[Liberty Times]] | location = [[Taipei]] | date = 3 May 2009 | accessdate = 24 January 2015 | language = Chinese}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | author = 林良昇 | script-title = 國際法觀點 學者：台灣被中華民國政府佔領70年 | trans-title = ⟨International Law Perspective⟩ Scholar: Taiwan Has Been Occupied by the Government of the Republic of China for 70 Years | url = http://news.ltn.com.tw/news/politics/breakingnews/1485820 | newspaper = [[Liberty Times]] | location = [[Taipei]] | date = 24 October 2015 | accessdate = 12 December 2015 | language = Chinese}}</ref>
Supporters of the theory include, but are not limited to, supporters of the [[Taiwan independence movement]]. They believe that Taiwan's status should be determined by [[Taiwanese people]] through [[self-determination]].
== See also == *[[General Order No. 1]] *[[Occupation of Japan]] *[[Treaty of San Francisco]] *[[Treaty of Taipei]] *[[Political status of Taiwan]] *[[History of Taiwan]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Politics of Taiwan]] [[Category:International relations]] [[Category:Cross-Strait relations]] [[Category:Political theories]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Cleanup|date=May 2009}} {{Expand Japanese|エフエム東京|date=May 2009}} {{Infobox Radio station | name = JOAU-FM | image = TokyoFMRadio.JPG | image_size = 175px | city = [[Chiyoda, Tokyo|Chiyoda]], [[Tokyo, Japan]] | area = [[Tokyo Metropolitan Area]] | branding = ''Tokyo FM'' | slogan = ''80.Love'' (pronounced as eighty-point-[[Names for the number 0 in English|love]]) (October 2008 – present) | airdate = April 26, 1970 | frequency = 80.0 [[Megahertz|MHz]] | format = [[Top 40 Mainstream]] | power = 10,000 [[watt]]s | erp = 125,000 watts | haat = | class = all | facility_id = | coordinates = | callsign_meaning = | former_callsigns = | owner = (As of March 31, 2015)
[[Tokai University]] (10.22%)
[[Tokyo Tower|Nippon Television City Corp.]] (7.28%)

[[Mizuho Capital]] (2.89%)『日本民間放送年鑑(Japan Commercial Broadcasting Yearbook)2015』, published by [[:Ja:日本民間放送連盟|The Japan Commercial Broadcasters Association]], 2015), page 273 | licensee = ''Tokyo FM Broadcasting Company'' | sister_stations = | webcast = [http://radiko.jp/#FMT Radiko.jp/#FMT] | website = [http://www.tfm.co.jp/ Tokyo FM Web site] | affiliations = [[Japan FM Network|JFN]], [[European Broadcasting Union|EBU]] }} {{nihongo|'''Tokyo FM Broadcasting Co., Ltd.'''|株式会社エフエム東京|Kabushiki Gaisha Efu Emu Tōkyō|literally '''FM Tokyo Co. Ltd.'''}} (abbreviation:TFM) is a radio station in [[Chiyoda, Tokyo|Chiyoda]], Tokyo, Japan. It is the [[flagship (broadcasting)|flagship station]] of the [[Japan FM Network]] (JFN). ==Timeline== *May 1, 1960, The station's forerunner, '''FM Tokai''' ([[Tokai University]]-owned) was launched. *April 26, 1970, Tokyo FM was launched on air, replacing the FM Tokai (station was closed in April 25, 1970). Tokyo FM becomes the third commercial FM-radio broadcaster, after [[:ja:エフエム愛知|FM Aichi]] and [[FM Osaka]]. *1985, Headquarter moved from Kokusai-Tsushin Center (later KDD, now [[KDDI]]) buildings in [[Nishi-Shinjuku]] (since 1974), to the current place, [[Koujimachi]], in [[Chiyoda,　Tokyo|Chiyoda]] ward. *January 15, 2017, TOKYO FM Midtown Studio, satellite studio, was closed down. ==Broadcasting== '''JOAU-FM''' *Frequency: 80.0 MHz ([[Tokyo Tower]]) {{RadioRebroadcasters | rec = | crtc = | notes = | callsign = JOAU-FM | call1 = N/A | freq1 = 76.7 MHz | watts1 = 100 | class1 = | city1 = [[Niijima, Tokyo|Niijima]] | call2 = N/A | freq2 = 84.3 MHz | watts2 = 10 | class2 = | city2 = [[Hachijo, Tokyo|Hachijo]] | call3 = N/A | freq3 = 83.6 MHz | watts3 = 20 | class3 = | city3 = [[Ōme, Tokyo|Ōme]] | call4 = N/A | freq4 = 80.5 MHz | watts4 = 10 | class4 = | city4 = [[Hachioji, Tokyo|Hachioji]] | call5 = N/A | freq5 = 86.6 MHz | watts5 = 300 | class5 = | city5 = [[Hinohara, Tokyo|Hinohara]] }} ==Program== *Countdown Station (simulcast over all [[Japan FM Network|JFN Stations]]) ** [[Zen-Noh]] presents Countdown jp ** [[Cosmo Oil|cosmo]] Pops Best 10 ** [[McDonald's]] SOUND IN MY LIFE *[[Tatsuro Yamashita]] presents [[JX Holdings|JX group]] Sunday Song Book *[[Suzuki]] Talking FM (hosted by [[Masaharu Fukuyama]]) *[[Morinaga Milk Industry|morinaga]] presents [[Ayaka Hirahara]] Healing Venus (simulcast over [[FM OSAKA]] and FM AICHI(@fm)) *[[Atsuko Maeda]]'s Heart Songs *''School of Lock!'' (simulcast over all [[Japan FM Network|JFN Stations]]) ==Website== *{{official website|http://www.tfm.co.jp/}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{JFN}} {{Tokyo Radio}} {{European Broadcasting Union Members}} [[Category:Media companies based in Tokyo]] [[Category:Radio stations in Japan]] {{Asia-radio-station-stub}} {{Japan-company-stub}}

{{For|the district in Kazakhstan|Ulytau District}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Ulytau
Ұлытау | image = | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Kazakhstan]] | genre = [[Folk metal]]
[[Neo-classical metal]] | years_active = 2001 – present | website = [http://www.ulytau.kz www.ulytau.kz] | current_members = Nurgaisha Sadvakasova
Yerzhan Alimbetov
Makism Kichigin }} '''Ulytau''' ({{lang-kz|Ұлытау}}), literally meaning "the great mountain", is a popular Turkic neopagan instrumental [[folk metal]] trio from [[Kazakhstan]].{{cite web |title=The Music of Ulytau |url=http://www.kazakhstanmediacentre.com/history/arts/ulytau.cfm |publisher=Kazakhstanmediacentre.com |accessdate=May 6, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080330212937/http://www.kazakhstanmediacentre.com/history/arts/ulytau.cfm |archivedate=March 30, 2008 |df= }} Their music combines the sound of the violin and electric guitar with the [[dombra]], a traditional two stringed instrument from their country. The band is named after the district of Ulytau in Central Kazakhstan, the mythical birthplace of the nation. ==Biography== Ulytau was conceived as a project by producer Kydyrali Bolmanov in 2001 to merge Western and Eastern music with arrangements of classical music from such composers as [[Kurmangazy Sagyrbayuly]], [[Antonio Vivaldi]], [[Niccolò Paganini]] and [[Johann Sebastian Bach]].{{cite web|title=History of the Creation |url=http://www.ulytau.kz/en/pages/2.jsp |publisher=Ulytau.kz |accessdate=May 6, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080401042539/http://www.ulytau.kz/en/pages/2.jsp |archivedate=April 1, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} They have since toured Germany, England, Scotland, Poland, USA, Turkey, China, Japan and Russia.{{cite web |title=Ulytau |publisher=Darksage.ru (In Russian) |url=http://darksage.ru/page/ULYTAU |accessdate=May 6, 2008}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} (Google translation: ''Despite the youth, musicians have already visited with tours in Germany, England, Scotland, Poland, USA, Turkey, China, Japan and, of course, Russia.'') The band was awarded the "Golden Disc" in 2001 for their song "Aday" that was based on a composition from Kurmangazy of the same name.[http://home-of-rock-news.blog.de/2009/06/19/ulytau-wanderer-welten-6345638/ ULYTAU – Wanderer zwischen Welten] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120709153331/http://home-of-rock-news.blog.de/2009/06/19/ulytau-wanderer-welten-6345638/ |date=2012-07-09 }} The song was also featured on the [[Rough Guides|Rough Guide]] compilation to the music of Central Asia.{{cite web |author=Greenberg, Adam |title=''The Rough Guide to the Music of Central Asia'' review |url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r727247|pure_url=yes}} |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=May 6, 2008}} ==Discography== *''Jumyr-Kylysh'' (2006) (In Germany released 2009 as ''Two Warriors'') ==Members== ===Line-up=== *Erjan Alimbetov - [[Dombra]] *Maxim Kichigin - Guitar *Alua Makanova - Violin ===Session musicians=== *Roman Adonin - Keyboards *Oleg Tarnovskiy - Guitar *Serik Sansyzbayev - Bass *Rafael Arslanov - Drums == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|URL=http://www.ulytau.kz/index.php?til=1}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Folk metal musical groups]] [[Category:Kazakhstani musical groups]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 2001]] {{Asia-band-stub}} {{Kazakhstan-stub}}
